div.p: THE QUAKERS QUAKING.
OR, The moſt juſt and deſerved puniſhment inflicted on the perſon of JAMES NAYLOR for his moſt horrid blaſphemies.

Together with the confeſſion of his Aſſociates, who were
Timothy Wedlock.
Thomas Symons.
John Stranger.
Hannah Stranger.
Martha Symons.
Dorcas Erbury.

As alſo the reaſons why the further puniſhment of the ſaid James Naylor was ſuſpended on Saturday, Decemb. 20. and deferred by order of Parliament untill Saturday, Decemb. 27. He remains ſtill a priſoner to Newgate, where many of his Aſſociates do daily reſort to him.
To which is added, The ſeverall damnable Opinions of the ſaid QUAKERS.

div.head: The Quakers quaking.
div.p: WE live now in the Evening of the World; and what our Savior did propheſie ſhould then come to paſſe, and did adviſe us to take héed of, is fulfiilled in our dayes: Take heed (ſaith our Saviour Ieſus Chriſt) in Luke 13. verſe 5. leſt any man deceive you, for many ſhall come in my name, ſaying, I am Chriſt, and ſhall deceive many. And in Matth. 24. verſe 20. our Saviour foretelling the ſtrong deluſions to come, doth adviſe us in theſe words: Therefore if any man ſhall ſay unto you, loe here is Chriſt, or there, believe it not, for there ſhall ariſe falſe Chriſts, and falſe Prophets, and ſhall ſhew ſigns and wonders, in ſo much that if it were poſſible they ſhall deceive the very elect.

The generation of Quakers, who had their originall in the North, have béen ſo fruitfull in a ſhort time, that they have infected a great part of the Weſt, and thouſands
in this populous City ſtand affected to them, being deluded by their pretended ſimplicity and zeale. You ſhall finde them maſters of ſo confident a ſpirit, as if the Oracles of truth did procéed onely out of their mouthes, and they muſt be caſt out to partake both of the ſhame and puniſhment of liars whoever ſhall endeavour to contradict them.

The names of George Fox and James Naylor have béen famous with many deluded people in this City, and they have made a mouth of many at the Mouth at Alderſgate At the laſt they began to quarrel among themſelves, and did in their way endeavour to excommunicate one another from their Congregations. It is ſaid that the latter of them, who both for his confeſſion and his puniſhments ſhall be the ſubject of this diſcourſe, hath béen accounted to have béen bewitched by the ſame creature, who having brought him to her will, did afterwards adore him; for it is manifeſt by the confeſſion of Martha Symons before the Mayor and Aldermen of Briſtol that ſhe had ſtruck the ſaid James Naylor into a trance for thrée daies together, which although the ſaid James Naylor did deny, yet being informed that the confeſſion
of Martha Symons did extend ſo far he was poſſeſſed with an amazing ſilence that ſo much ſhould be diſcovered of her ſtrength and his weakneſs.

But before I proceed to give you a Narrative of his blaſphemies, and how he was and would be adored as a new Ieſus. I will in the firſt place give you a character of his perſon, which is, that he is of about four and thirty years of age, a man of a good complexion brown hair, which he wears of an indiſterent length, but his beard was ſhort; he is of a melancholy aſpect, and he wears his hat hanging over his brows, his cloathes very plain; he wears a little band cloſe to his coller, without any band-ſtrings, as doth the other great Quaker George Fox; he doth ſtrive in his looks and poſture to imitate the Picture of our Saviour, as it was ſent up to Rome in the dayes of Tiberius Caeſar; and therefore he ſtrives to wear his hair as it were with a ſeam on the crown of his head, and ſo flowing down on each ſide of it. His parentage is of the meaneſt ranke, his father being ſaid to be a Sowgilder in Yorkſhire, in which County he himſelf was born, at a place called Anderſlow, and hath a Wife ſtill living at
Wakefield. In the time of the late wars he was a Souldier, and ſerved under the command of the Lord Fairfax, and afterwards under the command of Generall Lambert in Scotland, where he was a Quarter-maſter, and falling ſick he returned to his own Countrey, where he had not long continued but he was entred into the number of the Quakers, and coming to London grew acquainted with many women, with ſome of whom he was too familiar, and were inſtruments of his going down into the Weſt, where what horrid blaſphemies were broached by him in counterfeiting himſelf to be Ieſus the Saviour of mankind, the following Narration will advertiſe you. The comming of James Naylor into Briſtol, and the antick manner of Martha Symons waving her handkerchief, and ſinging, Holy, holy, holy, before him: and of Hannah ſtranger ſinging in the ſame manner, and of Dorcas Erbury pulling off his ſtockings, and laying her own cloathes beneath his féet, hath already béen diſcourſed by ſeveral Pens. I ſhall in this place give you the moſt material paſſages of all their examinations: and in the firſt place I will begin with
James Naylor, who being demanded whether he was the onely ſon of God, confeſſed that he was the ſon of God, but muſt acknowledge that he had many brethren.

div.head: The Examination of James Naylor.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Have any called thee by the Name of Jeſus?

div.p: A. Not as the viſible Ieſus, but as to Ieſus the Chriſt within me?

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Dareſt thou to own the name of the King of Iſrael?

div.p: A. Not as I am a creature, but if they give it Chriſt within me, I then doe own it, and I have a Kingdom, but not of this world, my kingdom is of another world, of which thou wiſts not.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Art thou the Prophet of the moſt high?

div.p: A. Thou haſt ſaid that I am a prophet.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Is not the written Word of God the guide?

div.p: A. It declares of it, and what is not according to that is not true.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Wert thou ever called the Lamb of God?

div.p:
A. There might be ſome ſuch thing in ſome Letter ſent, but I am a Lamb, and
have ſought it long before I could witneſs it.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Art thou the everlaſting Son of God?

div.p: A. I doe witneſs God in the fleſh I am the Son of God, and the Son of God is but one.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Art thou the Prince of peace?

div.p: A. The Prince of everlaſting peace is begotten in me.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Art thou the everlaſting Son of God?

div.p: A. I am and the everlaſting righteouſneſſe is wrought in me: if ye were acquainted with the Father, ye would alſo be acquainted with me.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Doſt thou live without bread?

div.p: A. As long as it ſhal pleaſe my heavenly Father, I have taſted of that bread of which he that eateth ſhall never die.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: How long haſt thou lived without corporall ſuſtenance?

div.p: A. Some fiftéen of ſixtéen daies, féeding on nothing but the Word of God.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Was Dorcas Erbury dead two daies in Exeter, and didſt thou raiſe her from the dead?

div.p: A I can do nothing of my ſelf, the Scripture beareth witneſſe to the power in me which is everlaſting: It is the ſame power I have which w • read in Scripture.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Art thou the unſpotted Lamb of God that taketh away the ſins of the world?

div.p: A. Were I not a Lamb, Wolves would not ſéek to devoure me.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Art not thou guilty of horrid blaſphemy by thy words?

div.p: A. Who made me a judge over them?

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Why cameſt thou in ſuch an unuſuall poſture riding into this City, with two women leading thy horſe, and ſinging, holy holy, holy; and another before thee bare headed, and knee deep in the mud, at ſuch a time that it raining moſt extreamly thy companions received it at their necks, and vented it at their hoſe and breeches.

div.p: A. It tended to my fathers praiſe and glory, and I ought not to ſlight any thing which the Spirit of the Lord moves.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Doſt thou think that the Spirit of the Lord moved them?

div.p: A. Yes.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Theſe books thou haſt written, wilt thou affirm what is therein.

div.p: A. Yea, with my deareſt blood.

div.head: The moſt material paſſages in the Examination of Martha Symons.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Doeſt thou owne James Naylor to be the Prince of peace?

div.p: A. He is a perfect man, and he that is a perfect man is the Prince of peace.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: What made thee to leave thy husband to follow James Naylor?

div.p: A. It is our life to praiſe the Lord.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Oughteſt thou to worſhip him upon thy knees?

div.p: A. I ought to do it.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: And wherefore ſo?

div.p: A. He is the Lord of righteouſneſſe, and the new man within him is the everlaſting Son of righteouſneſſe, and James Naylor will be Ieſus when the new man is born in him?

p.label: Q.
p.hi: By what name doſt thou call him?

div.p: A. Lord.

p.label: Q
p.hi: And why Lord?

div.p: A. Becauſe he is prince of peace, and Lord of righteouſneſs.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Why doſt thou call him King of Iſrael?

div.p: A. He is anointed.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Who anointed him?

div.p: A. A Prophet.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Who was that Prophet?

div.p: A. I will not tell thée.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Doth that ſpirit of Jeſus which thou ſayeſt is in him make a ſufficient Jeſus unto others?

div.p: A. There is a ſéed born in him which I and every one ought to honour.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Is he King of Iſrael, as thy Husband ſaith?

div.p: A. If he ſath ſo, thy teſtimony is double.

div.head: The moſt material paſſages in the Examination of Hannah Stranger.
div.p: Q. DOſt thou own Iames Naylor for the Prince of peace?
A. Yea, he is ſo.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: What doſt thou call his name?

div.p: A. It hath béen ſaid, I, and others have already told it.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Doſt thou not know it to be blaſphemy to give him ſuch and ſuch attributes?

div.p: A. If I have offended the Law, &c.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Didſt not thou ſend him that Letter wherein he is called the ſon of God?

div.p: A. Yes, I do own that Letter.
Being demanded why ſhe called him Ieſus, ſhe would return no anſwer at all.

div.head: The Examination of Timothy Wedlock.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Doſt thou own Iames Naylor to be the only ſon of God?

div.p: A. I do own him to be the ſon of God.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Wherefore didſt thou ſing before him Holy, holy, holy, Lord God of Iſrael?

div.p: A. I do own the ſongs of Sion.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Wherefore didſt thou go bare headed before him, when thou wilt not be uncovered before a Magiſtrate?

div.p: A. What I did was as the Lord commanded me.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Wherefore didſt thou kneel before him?

div.p: A.The truth made me.

div.head: The moſt material paſſages in the Examination of Dorcas Erbury the Relict of William Erbury, ſometime a Miniſter, but now a Quaker.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Doſt thou own him who rode on the Horſe to be the holy one of Iſrael?

div.p: A. Yea, I do, and with my bloud I will maintain it.

p.label: Q
p.hi: Doſt thou own him for the ſon of God?

div.p: A. He is the onely begotten ſon of God.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Wherefore didſt thou pull off his ſtockings, and lay thy cloathes at his feet?

div.p: A. He is worthy of it, for the is the holy one of Iſrael.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Knoweſt thou no other Jeſus, the only begotten ſon of God?

div.p: A. I know no other Saviour.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Doſt thou believe in Iames Naylor?

div.p: A. Yea, I do.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: By what name doſt thou call him?

div.p: A. The ſon of God, but I am to ſerve him, and to call him Lord and Maſter.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Jeſus was crucified, but this man is alive?

div.p: A. He hath ſhoke off his carnal body.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: What body hath he then?

div.p: A. Say not the Scriptures, the natural body I will change, and it ſhall be ſpiritual.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: But Chriſt raiſed thoſe who are dead, ſo hath not he?

div.p: A. He raiſed me.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: In what manner?

div.p: A. He laid his hand on my head when I had been dead two dayes, and ſaid unto me Dorcas ariſe, and I aroſe and live as thou ſeeſt.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: What witneſſe haſt thou for this?

div.p: A. My mother who was preſent.

p.label: Q.
p.hi: Jeſus Chriſt doth ſit at the right hand of the Father, when the world ſhall be judged by him?

div.p: A. He whom thou calleſt Naylor, ſhall ſit at the right hand of the Father, and ſhall judge the world with equity.

div.head: The Subſtance of ſeveral Letters ſent to the ſaid James Naylor.
div.p: HAnnah Stranger in her Letter to him calls him The everlaſting Son of righteouſneſs, and Prince of Peace.

And in another place writing to the ſaid Naylor, ſhe hath theſe words, The Lord ſhall not ſuffer his holy one to ſee corruption, nor his ſoul to lie in Hell; but will cauſe the mountains to melt at his preſence, and the little hills to bring him Peace.

And in another Letter, ſhe calls him the faireſt of ten thouſand, the onely begotten Son of God; her heart panteth after him. Her Husband in his Letter to him, telleth
him that his name, is no more to be called James but Jeſus: and this he owned at his Examination.

list.head: The Opinions of the Quakers are theſe.
list.item: 1. They deny the Scriptures to be the Word of God.
2. They eſteem their own ſpeakings to be of as much Authority.
3. They hold it lawful to expound, or to interpret the Scriptures.
4. They ſay, He that preacheth by a Text of Scripture is a Conjurer.
5. They affirm that the holy letter is carnal.
6. That the Bible ought to be burned.
7. That Jeſus Chriſt inhabiteth in the fleſh of Man.
8. Some of them have ſaid, that Chriſt never aſcended into Heaven.
9. That to pray that their ſins may be pardoned is needleſs.
10. That they believe not that there is another World.
11. Some of them deny the Reſurrection.
12. They affirm they cannot ſin, but are perfect.
13. They make no diſtinction of Perſons.

div.p: According to the Sentence paſſed upon him, the ſaid Iames Naylor ſtood in the Pillory, was whipped on Thurſday laſt being December 18. from the Palace-yard in Weſtminſter to the Royal-Exchange: and the further proſecution of his Sentence had been put in Execution on Saturday December 20, but by an Order from the Parliament, the ſaid Naylor pretending ſickneſs, it is deferred until Saturday December twenty Seven, at which time he is to receive his juſt Reward, according to his deſert.
